climbs.name: You Might Not Make it to the Gables

content.description:
The line follows some decent, grippy holds and high feet, to an obvious horizontal crack. This is where the crux is, from the crack, you need to paste feet high on the wall and commit to two small crimps, until you make it to the right facing flake, from there it's easy street, with all positive holds, over the round lip. Suggest you either TR or practice the moves on TR before making an attempt.  

  Video of the original ascent (wide angle of the GoPro does the height of this line no justice; it's very high): 

youtu.be/Wtb24nVlte4
content.protection: Bring at least 3-4 pads lol. I guess you could use some gear to protect the crux if you want in the horizontal, but the original line was a solo, so honestly I don't have any beta on piece sizes (plus this rock tends to be pebbly and kitty litter like consistency, so be careful trusting gear).
content.location: From the Granite St parking lot, make your way down the green trail towards fern gully (right at trail T, cross the two bridges, cross the swampy road/river crossing), then follow the band down until you reach the really high slab walls. It is the obvious, scrubbed line/holds on the wall.

content.description: This is a nice little problem that will teach a beginner to use their feet or suffer the pain that is involved in crimping sharp cystals.
content.location: this is the slab to the right of the big Y crack and it climbs the tallest part of the slab. The arete is off.

content.description: Tall low angle slab/face climb with a really nice sequence all the way to the jug at the top.
content.location: This route stands by itself on the edge of the swamp. It is surrounded by unclean and undone problems. From the parking on Granite rd take the green trail across the power lines, when you see the 3rd bridge (30 seconds from the power line crossing) cut right to some visible piles of rock. Swampy pants is the first nice rock on the right.

content.description: Climb the arete to the left of the Y crack. Make a couple of moves to get the jug and top out.
Starts on the slab in the picture and follows the crack feature to a pretty easy but scary topout. Crux is making a committing move to a good crimp right before the topout.
content.location: The first cliff you come to after parking at the end of Granite Road. Its right where the old White trail intersects with the Green-Orange trail.

content.description: the main event here. nice moves on small feet and small hands. balancy with a juggy topout
content.location: left of safety bar arete up the center and tallest part of the wall

content.description: nice problem with juggy hands in a crack to start and a very nice right hand sloping sidepull in the middle. another nice juggy topout.
content.location: far left on warmup wall. starts right behind the vagrant hiker sitting on the pad

content.description:
This area appears to on GLCT property where rock climbing is prohibited. Please obey all Land Trust rules. Climbs are listed for informational/historic purposes. 

  This is the area closest to the Granite Rd parking spot mainly covering the cliff-band that parallels Granite Rd and crosses the power lines. The climbs are on both sides of the power lines.
